column2: Let down the bars, O Death! The tired flocks come in Whose bleating ceases to repeat, Whose wandering is done.
column3: Let down the bars, O Death! The tired flocks come in Whose bleating ceases to repeat, Whose wandering is done.

column2: -- How dim it sounds! And yet it will be done As sure as flocks go home at night Unto the shepherd's arm!
column3: -- How dim it sounds! And yet it will be done As sure as flocks go home at night Unto the shepherd's arm!

column2: The smallest "robe" will fit me, And just a bit of "crown;" For you know we do not mind our dress When we are going home.
column3: The smallest "robe" will fit me, And just a bit of "crown;" For you know we do not mind our dress When we are going home.

column2: III.
column3: three.

column2: At least to pray is left, is left. O Jesus! in the air I know not which thy chamber is, -- I 'm knocking everywhere.
column3: At least to pray is left, is left. O Jesus! in the air I know not which thy chamber is, -- I 'm knocking everywhere.

column2: Thou stirrest earthquake in the South, And maelstrom in the sea; Say, Jesus Christ of Nazareth, Hast thou no arm for me?
column3: Thou stirrest earthquake in the South, And maelstrom in the sea; Say, Jesus Christ of Nazareth, Hast thou no arm for me?

column2: EPITAPH.
column3: EPITAPH.

column2: Step lightly on this narrow spot! The broadest land that grows Is not so ample as the breast These emerald seams enclose.
column3: Step lightly on this narrow spot! The broadest land that grows Is not so ample as the breast These emerald seams enclose.

column2: Step lofty; for this name is told As far as cannon dwell, Or flag subsist, or fame export Her deathless syllable.
column3: Step lofty; for this name is told As far as cannon dwell, Or flag subsist, or fame export Her deathless syllable.

column2: Morns like these we parted; Noons like these she rose, Fluttering first, then firmer, To her fair repose.
column3: Morns like these we parted; Noons like these she rose, Fluttering first, then firmer, To her fair repose.

column2: Never did she lisp it, And 't was not for me; She was mute from transport, I, from agony!
column3: Never did she lisp it, And 't was not for me; She was mute from transport, I, from agony!

column2: Till the evening, nearing, One the shutters drew -- Quick! a sharper rustling! And this linnet flew!
column3: Till the evening, nearing, One the shutters drew -- Quick! a sharper rustling! And this linnet flew!

column2: A death-blow is a life-blow to some Who, till they died, did not alive become; Who, had they lived, had died, but when They died, vitality begun.
column3: A death blow is a life blow to some Who, till they died, did not alive become; Who, had they lived, had died, but when They died, vitality begun.

column2: VII.
column3: seven.

column2: I read my sentence steadily, Reviewed it with my eyes, To see that I made no mistake In its extremest clause, --
column3: I read my sentence steadily, Reviewed it with my eyes, To see that I made no mistake In its extremest clause, --

column2: The date, and manner of the shame; And then the pious form That "God have mercy" on the soul The jury voted him.
column3: The date, and manner of the shame; And then the pious form That "God have mercy" on the soul The jury voted him.

column2: I made my soul familiar With her extremity, That at the last it should not be A novel agony,
column3: I made my soul familiar With her extremity, That at the last it should not be A novel agony,

column2: But she and Death, acquainted, Meet tranquilly as friends, Salute and pass without a hint -- And there the matter ends.
column3: But she and Death, acquainted, Meet tranquilly as friends, Salute and pass without a hint -- And there the matter ends.

column2: VIII.
column3: eight.

column2: I have not told my garden yet, Lest that should conquer me; I have not quite the strength now To break it to the bee.
column3: I have not told my garden yet, Lest that should conquer me; I have not quite the strength now To break it to the bee.

column2: I will not name it in the street, For shops would stare, that I, So shy, so very ignorant, Should have the face to die.
column3: I will not name it in the street, For shops would stare, that I, So shy, so very ignorant, Should have the face to die.

column2: The hillsides must not know it, Where I have rambled so, Nor tell the loving forests The day that I shall go,
column3: The hillsides must not know it, Where I have rambled so, Nor tell the loving forests The day that I shall go,

column2: Nor lisp it at the table, Nor heedless by the way Hint that within the riddle One will walk to-day!
column3: Nor lisp it at the table, Nor heedless by the way Hint that within the riddle One will walk to day!

column2: THE BATTLE-FIELD.
column3: THE BATTLE FIELD.

column2: They dropped like flakes, they dropped like stars, Like petals from a rose, When suddenly across the June A wind with fingers goes.
column3: They dropped like flakes, they dropped like stars, Like petals from a rose, When suddenly across the June A wind with fingers goes.

column2: The only ghost I ever saw Was dressed in mechlin, -- so; He wore no sandal on his foot, And stepped like flakes of snow. His gait was soundless, like the bird, But rapid, like the roe; His fashions quaint, mosaic, Or, haply, mistletoe.
column3: The only ghost I ever saw Was dressed in mechlin, -- so; He wore no sandal on his foot, And stepped like flakes of snow. His gait was soundless, like the bird, But rapid, like the roe; His fashions quaint, mosaic, Or, haply, mistletoe.

column2: Some, too fragile for winter winds, The thoughtful grave encloses, -- Tenderly tucking them in from frost Before their feet are cold.
column3: Some, too fragile for winter winds, The thoughtful grave encloses, -- Tenderly tucking them in from frost Before their feet are cold.

column2: Never the treasures in her nest The cautious grave exposes, Building where schoolboy dare not look And sportsman is not bold.
column3: Never the treasures in her nest The cautious grave exposes, Building where schoolboy dare not look And sportsman is not bold.

column2: XII.
column3: twelve.

column2: As by the dead we love to sit, Become so wondrous dear, As for the lost we grapple, Though all the rest are here, --
column3: As by the dead we love to sit, Become so wondrous dear, As for the lost we grapple, Though all the rest are here, --

column2: In broken mathematics We estimate our prize, Vast, in its fading ratio, To our penurious eyes!
column3: In broken mathematics We estimate our prize, Vast, in its fading ratio, To our penurious eyes!

column2: XIII.
column3: thirteen.

column2: MEMORIALS.
column3: MEMORIALS.

column2: Death sets a thing significant The eye had hurried by, Except a perished creature Entreat us tenderly
column3: Death sets a thing significant The eye had hurried by, Except a perished creature Entreat us tenderly

column2: To ponder little workmanships In crayon or in wool, With "This was last her fingers did," Industrious until
column3: To ponder little workmanships In crayon or in wool, With "This was last her fingers did," Industrious until

column2: The thimble weighed too heavy, The stitches stopped themselves, And then 't was put among the dust Upon the closet shelves.
column3: The thimble weighed too heavy, The stitches stopped themselves, And then 't was put among the dust Upon the closet shelves.

column2: A book I have, a friend gave, Whose pencil, here and there, Had notched the place that pleased him, -- At rest his fingers are.
column3: A book I have, a friend gave, Whose pencil, here and there, Had notched the place that pleased him, -- At rest his fingers are.

column2: Now, when I read, I read not, For interrupting tears Obliterate the etchings Too costly for repairs.
column3: Now, when I read, I read not, For interrupting tears Obliterate the etchings Too costly for repairs.

column2: XIV.
column3: fourteen.

column2: I went to heaven, -- 'T was a small town, Lit with a ruby, Lathed with down. Stiller than the fields At the full dew, Beautiful as pictures No man drew. People like the moth, Of mechlin, frames, Duties of gossamer, And eider names. Almost contented I could be 'Mong such unique Society.
column3: I went to heaven, -- 'T was a small town, Lit with a ruby, Lathed with down. Stiller than the fields At the full dew, Beautiful as pictures No man drew. People like the moth, Of mechlin, frames, Duties of gossamer, And eider names. Almost contented I could be 'Mong such unique Society.

column2: XV.
column3: fifteen.

column2: The house of supposition, The glimmering frontier That skirts the acres of perhaps, To me shows insecure.
column3: The house of supposition, The glimmering frontier That skirts the acres of perhaps, To me shows insecure.

column2: Better than larger values, However true their show; This timid life of evidence Keeps pleading, "I don't know."
column3: Better than larger values, However true their show; This timid life of evidence Keeps pleading, "I don't know."

column2: XVI.
column3: sixteen.

column2: There is a shame of nobleness Confronting sudden pelf, -- A finer shame of ecstasy Convicted of itself.
column3: There is a shame of nobleness Confronting sudden pelf, -- A finer shame of ecstasy Convicted of itself.

column2: A triumph when temptation's bribe Is slowly handed back, One eye upon the heaven renounced And one upon the rack.
column3: A triumph when temptation's bribe Is slowly handed back, One eye upon the heaven renounced And one upon the rack.

column2: XVIII.
column3: eighteen.

column2: XIX.
column3: nineteen.

column2: I noticed people disappeared, When but a little child, -- Supposed they visited remote, Or settled regions wild.
column3: I noticed people disappeared, When but a little child, -- Supposed they visited remote, Or settled regions wild.

column2: FOLLOWING.
column3: FOLLOWING.

column2: I had no cause to be awake, My best was gone to sleep, And morn a new politeness took, And failed to wake them up,
column3: I had no cause to be awake, My best was gone to sleep, And morn a new politeness took, And failed to wake them up,

column2: But called the others clear, And passed their curtains by. Sweet morning, when I over-sleep, Knock, recollect, for me!
column3: But called the others clear, And passed their curtains by. Sweet morning, when I over sleep, Knock, recollect, for me!

column2: I looked at sunrise once, And then I looked at them, And wishfulness in me arose For circumstance the same.
column3: I looked at sunrise once, And then I looked at them, And wishfulness in me arose For circumstance the same.

column2: So choosing but a gown And taking but a prayer, The only raiment I should need, I struggled, and was there.
column3: So choosing but a gown And taking but a prayer, The only raiment I should need, I struggled, and was there.

column2: XXI.
column3: twenty one.

column2: Their costume, of a Sunday, Some manner of the hair, -- A prank nobody knew but them, Lost, in the sepulchre.
column3: Their costume, of a Sunday, Some manner of the hair, -- A prank nobody knew but them, Lost, in the sepulchre.

column2: You asked the company to tea, Acquaintance, just a few, And chatted close with this grand thing That don't remember you?
column3: You asked the company to tea, Acquaintance, just a few, And chatted close with this grand thing That don't remember you?

column2: Past bows and invitations, Past interview, and vow, Past what ourselves can estimate, -- That makes the quick of woe!
column3: Past bows and invitations, Past interview, and vow, Past what ourselves can estimate, -- That makes the quick of woe!

column2: THE JOURNEY.
column3: THE JOURNEY.

column2: Our journey had advanced; Our feet were almost come To that odd fork in Being's road, Eternity by term.
column3: Our journey had advanced; Our feet were almost come To that odd fork in Being's road, Eternity by term.

column2: Our pace took sudden awe, Our feet reluctant led. Before were cities, but between, The forest of the dead.
column3: Our pace took sudden awe, Our feet reluctant led. Before were cities, but between, The forest of the dead.

column2: XXIII.
column3: twenty three.

column2: A COUNTRY BURIAL.
column3: A COUNTRY BURIAL.

column2: Be its mattress straight, Be its pillow round; Let no sunrise' yellow noise Interrupt this ground.
column3: Be its mattress straight, Be its pillow round; Let no sunrise' yellow noise Interrupt this ground.

column2: XXIV.
column3: twenty four.

column2: GOING.
column3: GOING.

column2: On such a night, or such a night, Would anybody care If such a little figure Slipped quiet from its chair,
column3: On such a night, or such a night, Would anybody care If such a little figure Slipped quiet from its chair,

column2: So quiet, oh, how quiet! That nobody might know But that the little figure Rocked softer, to and fro?
column3: So quiet, oh, how quiet! That nobody might know But that the little figure Rocked softer, to and fro?

column2: On such a dawn, or such a dawn, Would anybody sigh That such a little figure Too sound asleep did lie
column3: On such a dawn, or such a dawn, Would anybody sigh That such a little figure Too sound asleep did lie

column2: For chanticleer to wake it, -- Or stirring house below, Or giddy bird in orchard, Or early task to do?
column3: For chanticleer to wake it, -- Or stirring house below, Or giddy bird in orchard, Or early task to do?

column2: There was a little figure plump For every little knoll, Busy needles, and spools of thread, And trudging feet from school.
column3: There was a little figure plump For every little knoll, Busy needles, and spools of thread, And trudging feet from school.

column2: Playmates, and holidays, and nuts, And visions vast and small. Strange that the feet so precious charged Should reach so small a goal!
column3: Playmates, and holidays, and nuts, And visions vast and small. Strange that the feet so precious charged Should reach so small a goal!

column2: XXV.
column3: twenty five.

column2: The general rose decays; But this, in lady's drawer, Makes summer when the lady lies In ceaseless rosemary.
column3: The general rose decays; But this, in lady's drawer, Makes summer when the lady lies In ceaseless rosemary.

column2: XXVI.
column3: twenty six.

column2: I lived on dread; to those who know The stimulus there is In danger, other impetus Is numb and vital-less.
column3: I lived on dread; to those who know The stimulus there is In danger, other impetus Is numb and vital less.

column2: XXVIII.
column3: twenty eight.

column2: AT LENGTH.
column3: AT LENGTH.

column2: Her final summer was it, And yet we guessed it not; If tenderer industriousness Pervaded her, we thought
column3: Her final summer was it, And yet we guessed it not; If tenderer industriousness Pervaded her, we thought

column2: A further force of life Developed from within, -- When Death lit all the shortness up, And made the hurry plain.
column3: A further force of life Developed from within, -- When Death lit all the shortness up, And made the hurry plain.

column2: We wondered at our blindness, -- When nothing was to see But her Carrara guide-post, -- At our stupidity,
column3: We wondered at our blindness, -- When nothing was to see But her Carrara guide post, -- At our stupidity,

column2: When, duller than our dulness, The busy darling lay, So busy was she, finishing, So leisurely were we!
column3: When, duller than our dulness, The busy darling lay, So busy was she, finishing, So leisurely were we!

column2: XXIX.
column3: twenty nine.

column2: One need not be a chamber to be haunted, One need not be a house; The brain has corridors surpassing Material place.
column3: One need not be a chamber to be haunted, One need not be a house; The brain has corridors surpassing Material place.

column2: Far safer, of a midnight meeting External ghost, Than an interior confronting That whiter host.
column3: Far safer, of a midnight meeting External ghost, Than an interior confronting That whiter host.

column2: Far safer through an Abbey gallop, The stones achase, Than, moonless, one's own self encounter In lonesome place.
column3: Far safer through an Abbey gallop, The stones achase, Than, moonless, one's own self encounter In lonesome place.

column2: Ourself, behind ourself concealed, Should startle most; Assassin, hid in our apartment, Be horror's least.
column3: Ourself, behind ourself concealed, Should startle most; Assassin, hid in our apartment, Be horror's least.

column2: VANISHED.
column3: VANISHED.

column2: She died, -- this was the way she died; And when her breath was done, Took up her simple wardrobe And started for the sun.
column3: She died, -- this was the way she died; And when her breath was done, Took up her simple wardrobe And started for the sun

column2: Her little figure at the gate The angels must have spied, Since I could never find her Upon the mortal side.
column3: Her little figure at the gate The angels must have spied, Since I could never find her Upon the mortal side.

column2: XXXI.
column3: thirty one.

column2: PRECEDENCE.
column3: PRECEDENCE.

column2: Wait till the majesty of Death Invests so mean a brow! Almost a powdered footman Might dare to touch it now!
column3: Wait till the majesty of Death Invests so mean a brow! Almost a powdered footman Might dare to touch it now!

column2: Wait till in everlasting robes This democrat is dressed, Then prate about "preferment" And "station" and the rest!
column3: Wait till in everlasting robes This democrat is dressed, Then prate about "preferment" And "station" and the rest!

column2: Around this quiet courtier Obsequious angels wait! Full royal is his retinue, Full purple is his state!
column3: Around this quiet courtier Obsequious angels wait! Full royal is his retinue, Full purple is his state!

column2: GONE.
column3: GONE.

column2: Beguiling thus the wonder, The wondrous nearer drew; Hands bustled at the moorings -- The crowd respectful grew. Ascended from our vision To countenances new! A difference, a daisy, Is all the rest I knew!
column3: Beguiling thus the wonder, The wondrous nearer drew; Hands bustled at the moorings -- The crowd respectful grew. Ascended from our vision To countenances new! A difference, a daisy, Is all the rest I knew!

column2: XXXIII.
column3: thirty three.

column2: REQUIEM.
column3: REQUIEM.

column2: Taken from men this morning, Carried by men to-day, Met by the gods with banners Who marshalled her away.
column3: Taken from men this morning, Carried by men to day, Met by the gods with banners Who marshalled her away.

column2: One little maid from playmates, One little mind from school, -- There must be guests in Eden; All the rooms are full.
column3: One little maid from playmates, One little mind from school, -- There must be guests in Eden; All the rooms are full.

column2: XXXIV.
column3: thirty four.

column2: What inn is this Where for the night Peculiar traveller comes? Who is the landlord? Where the maids? Behold, what curious rooms! No ruddy fires on the hearth, No brimming tankards flow. Necromancer, landlord, Who are these below?
column3: What inn is this Where for the night Peculiar traveller comes? Who is the landlord? Where the maids? Behold, what curious rooms! No ruddy fires on the hearth, No brimming tankards flow. Necromancer, landlord, Who are these below?

column2: XXXV.
column3: thirty five.

column2: It was not death, for I stood up, And all the dead lie down; It was not night, for all the bells Put out their tongues, for noon.
column3: It was not death, for I stood up, And all the dead lie down; It was not night, for all the bells Put out their tongues, for noon.

column2: It was not frost, for on my flesh I felt siroccos crawl, -- Nor fire, for just my marble feet Could keep a chancel cool.
column3: It was not frost, for on my flesh I felt siroccos crawl, -- Nor fire, for just my marble feet Could keep a chancel cool.

column2: And yet it tasted like them all; The figures I have seen Set orderly, for burial, Reminded me of mine,
column3: And yet it tasted like them all; The figures I have seen Set orderly, for burial, Reminded me of mine,

column2: As if my life were shaven And fitted to a frame, And could not breathe without a key; And 't was like midnight, some,
column3: As if my life were shaven And fitted to a frame, And could not breathe without a key; And 't was like midnight, some,

column2: When everything that ticked has stopped, And space stares, all around, Or grisly frosts, first autumn morns, Repeal the beating ground.
column3: When everything that ticked has stopped, And space stares, all around, Or grisly frosts, first autumn morns, Repeal the beating ground.

column2: But most like chaos, -- stopless, cool, -- Without a chance or spar, Or even a report of land To justify despair.
column3: But most like chaos, -- stopless, cool, -- Without a chance or spar, Or even a report of land To justify despair.

column2: XXXVI.
column3: thirty six.

column2: TILL THE END.
column3: TILL THE END.

column2: If I should disappoint the eyes That hunted, hunted so, to see, And could not bear to shut until They "noticed" me -- they noticed me;
column3: If I should disappoint the eyes That hunted, hunted so, to see, And could not bear to shut until They "noticed" me -- they noticed me;

column2: My heart would wish it broke before, Since breaking then, since breaking then, Were useless as next morning's sun, Where midnight frosts had lain!
column3: My heart would wish it broke before, Since breaking then, since breaking then, Were useless as next morning's sun, Where midnight frosts had lain!

column2: VOID.
column3: VOID.

column2: Great streets of silence led away To neighborhoods of pause; Here was no notice, no dissent, No universe, no laws.
column3: Great streets of silence led away To neighborhoods of pause; Here was no notice, no dissent, No universe, no laws.

column2: By clocks 't was morning, and for night The bells at distance called; But epoch had no basis here, For period exhaled.
column3: By clocks 't was morning, and for night The bells at distance called; But epoch had no basis here, For period exhaled.

column2: XXXVIII.
column3: thirty eight.

column2: A throe upon the features A hurry in the breath, An ecstasy of parting Denominated "Death," --
column3: A throe upon the features A hurry in the breath, An ecstasy of parting Denominated "Death," --

column2: XXXIX.
column3: thirty nine.

column2: SAVED!
column3: SAVED!

column2: Of tribulation these are they Denoted by the white; The spangled gowns, a lesser rank Of victors designate.
column3: Of tribulation these are they Denoted by the white; The spangled gowns, a lesser rank Of victors designate.

column2: All these did conquer; but the ones Who overcame most times Wear nothing commoner than snow, No ornament but palms.
column3: All these did conquer; but the ones Who overcame most times Wear nothing commoner than snow, No ornament but palms.

column2: Surrender is a sort unknown On this superior soil; Defeat, an outgrown anguish, Remembered as the mile
column3: Surrender is a sort unknown On this superior soil; Defeat, an outgrown anguish, Remembered as the mile

column2: Our panting ankle barely gained When night devoured the road; But we stood whispering in the house, And all we said was "Saved"!
column3: Our panting ankle barely gained When night devoured the road; But we stood whispering in the house, And all we said was "Saved"!

column2: I think just how my shape will rise When I shall be forgiven, Till hair and eyes and timid head Are out of sight, in heaven.
column3: I think just how my shape will rise When I shall be forgiven, Till hair and eyes and timid head Are out of sight, in heaven.

column2: I think just how my lips will weigh With shapeless, quivering prayer That you, so late, consider me, The sparrow of your care.
column3: I think just how my lips will weigh With shapeless, quivering prayer That you, so late, consider me, The sparrow of your care.

column2: I mind me that of anguish sent, Some drifts were moved away Before my simple bosom broke, -- And why not this, if they?
column3: I mind me that of anguish sent, Some drifts were moved away Before my simple bosom broke, -- And why not this, if they?

column2: And so, until delirious borne I con that thing, -- "forgiven," -- Till with long fright and longer trust I drop my heart, unshriven!
column3: And so, until delirious borne I con that thing, -- "forgiven," -- Till with long fright and longer trust I drop my heart, unshriven!

column2: THE FORGOTTEN GRAVE.
column3: THE FORGOTTEN GRAVE.

column2: After a hundred years Nobody knows the place, -- Agony, that enacted there, Motionless as peace.
column3: After a hundred years Nobody knows the place, -- Agony, that enacted there, Motionless as peace.

column2: Weeds triumphant ranged, Strangers strolled and spelled At the lone orthography Of the elder dead.
column3: Weeds triumphant ranged, Strangers strolled and spelled At the lone orthography Of the elder dead.
